examTips: Focus on duty of care, disclosure, conflicts and legal capacity.

questions.question: Pssst. . . . Would you like a very important exam tip that may save you time on the exam and improve your result?
options: Absolutely
No
Maybe
Definitely not
optionFeedback: In a timed exam like the LLQP, every strategy counts! Understanding how to navigate long ethics scenarios is key to passing.
You definitely want this one. Reading the question before the scenario helps you avoid 'distractor' information in the case study.
Skipping strategies can lead to running out of time on the 20-question Ethics module.
questions.explanation: The tip is RTQF: Read The Question First. In long ethics scenarios, don't start with the story. Read the actual question at the bottom first so you know what details to look for in the scenario.

questions.question:
(PPE-047) EPP
Donald was injured when a skid at Home Depot fell from an upper shelf and landed on his shoulder and upper back. After pursuing the matter in court, he was awarded $1,000,000 to compensate for the loss of his ability to earn an income.
What tax implications would be associated with the award?
options: Half of the award would be received tax free.
He would receive it tax free.
It would be taxed as regular income in the taxation year received.
It would be taxed as regular income; however, the taxation could be spread out evenly until age 65.
optionFeedback: There is no provision in the Income Tax Act that taxes only half of a personal injury award.
Personal injury awards are not considered 'income' for taxation purposes under Section 81(1)(g.1) of the Income Tax Act.
While structured settlements allow for periodic payments, the principal award for personal injury remains non-taxable regardless of the payout timing.
questions.explanation:
In Canada, the CRA (Bulletin IT-365R2) states that all amounts received as special or general damages for personal injury or death are excluded from income, even if the amount was determined with reference to a loss of earnings.

Damages for personal injury caused by a negligent third party are considered to be compensation for the loss of an ability to earn an income (not income itself) and therefore are received tax free.

Think about it this way‚Äîyou pay tax when you actually earn income; however, you are not taxed simply because you are physically able to work. Likewise, Donald's settlement is not considered taxable income. Instead, it should be thought of as a settlement for an injured shoulder and back that now prevent him from enjoying certain aspects of life, including the ability to work.

questions.question:
(PPE-036) EPP
Dante is a captive insurance agent with Willis Insurance. Bruno enters Dante's office with a third-party cheque for $250,000 that he would like to use to purchase an annuity. Bruno is withdrawn and nervous, and he seems more interested in the consequences of terminating the annuity than its long-term advantages.

How should Dante proceed?
options: Dante should report the transaction to FINTRAC within 30 days as a suspicious transaction.
Dante should report the transaction to CISRO within 30 days as a suspicious transaction.
Dante should report the transaction to FSCO within 30 days as a suspicious transaction.
Dante should report the transaction to PIPEDA within 30 days as a suspicious transaction.
optionFeedback: CISRO is not the correct agency for reporting suspicious financial transactions in Canada.
FSCO (Financial Services Commission of Ontario) is not the federal agency responsible for anti-money laundering reports.
PIPEDA is privacy legislation, not the agency for reporting suspicious transactions.
questions.explanation:
FINTRAC is Canada's financial intelligence agency responsible for receiving and analyzing reports of suspicious financial transactions to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. Insurance agents must report suspicious transactions to FINTRAC within 30 days.

Suspicious transactions or even an attempt at a transaction that appears suspicious must be reported to FINTRAC within 30 days.

The following are things that should be viewed as red flags (hints that something isn't right):
‚Ä¢ The client does not want to provide identification documents.
‚Ä¢ The client seems nervous.
‚Ä¢ The client is unusually curious about internal controls.
‚Ä¢ The client deposits third-party cheques for large amounts (cheques written to him or her by someone else).
‚Ä¢ The client is more interested in how to cancel a transaction than the long-term nature of the product (i.e. may want to just put the money in and then withdraw it to make it look as if it came from a legitimate source).
‚Ä¢ The transaction is more complex than it needs to be (i.e. the client is trying to blur an audit trail).
‚Ä¢ The transaction does not seem to fit the client's risk tolerance or client profile.
‚Ä¢ The client uses a post office box and lives in an area where that is not common.

questions.question:
(PPE-015) EPP
Which of the following deaths could be excluded on an AD&D policy?
I. Joel, who died while racing his brother on snowmobiles at the family cottage.
II. Paul, who lost a leg from frostbite when he got lost for several days during a winter hike.
III. Michael, who died after being hit by a car as he ran away from a security guard after sneaking into a movie without paying.
IV. Nancy, who accidentally died from a drug overdose.
options: IV
I, III, IV
III, IV
I, II, III, IV
optionFeedback: While Nancy's death could be excluded under drug/alcohol clauses, she is not the only one.
This omitted Joel, whose death while racing is also a standard exclusion for hazardous hobbies.
Paul (II) lost a leg but did not die. Since the question asks specifically for 'deaths,' Paul's scenario does not fit the criteria.
questions.explanation:
Joel died during a high-risk/racing activity, Michael died while committing/fleeing an illegal act, and Nancy died from a drug-related cause‚Äîall common exclusions. Paul (II) is not included because he did not die; he suffered a dismemberment, so his case is not an "excluded death".

Note: Only Paul's loss would be covered.

Additional Learning:
‚Ä¢ Joel's death would be excluded because vehicle racing is an exclusion on an accidental death and dismemberment policy.
‚Ä¢ Michael's death was caused by an illegal act (sneaking into a theater without paying is considered theft).
‚Ä¢ Nancy's death would not be considered accidental because she intentionally took the drugs that caused her death.

questions.question:
(PPE-003) EPP
Joshua applied for a $250,000 participating whole life insurance policy. He answered "No" to all of the applicable health-related questions and submitted the first monthly premium along with the application. At the time, he was provided with a temporary insurance agreement (TIA) that provided him with interim coverage during the underwriting process. The TIA covered him for the lesser of $100,000 or the amount for which he was applying under the main policy. A few days later, the initial premium was returned for non-sufficient funds (NSF) from Joshua's financial institution.
What impact would this have on the TIA?
options: The TIA would not be in force.
The TIA has already been issued and would remain in force. In the event of a claim, the first month's premium would be deducted from the death benefit.
The TIA would lapse after a 31-day grace period.
The initial premium is for the main policy; therefore, the TIA would still remain in force.
optionFeedback: Unlike a policy already in force, a TIA is strictly conditional upon the actual payment of the initial premium.
Grace periods (typically 30-31 days) only apply to existing policies that have already taken effect, not to the initial TIA application process.
The TIA and the main policy application are linked by the same initial premium; without the payment, the interim coverage fails.
questions.explanation:
A TIA is a conditional contract that only takes effect if the required "consideration" (the premium) is received. Because the check was returned for NSF, the premium was never truly received, meaning the TIA never came into force.

A temporary insurance agreement exposes the insurer to some level of risk during the underwriting process and therefore should not be issued, unless some form of "consideration" (premium) has been received by the insurer.

An agent should never give a client a TIA unless:
‚Ä¢ The client answered "No" to all the applicable health questions, such as "Have you ever been diagnosed with cancer?"
‚Ä¢ The agent has no reason to disbelieve the client's answers.
‚Ä¢ The client has paid the first premium via cheque or pre-authorized debit.

Note: In order for the TIA to be considered in force, the first premium payment must also be honoured by the financial institution from which it is drawn. A statement to this effect would be included in the terms and conditions of the TIA.

questions.question:
(PPE-029) EPP
Victor is a licensed life insurance agent. When discussing retirement planning for his client Joseph, it became clear that Joseph was risk averse. His risk tolerance would likely cause Joseph to not meet his goal of retirement at age 55. Victor placed Joseph's portfolio in a high-risk equity fund knowing it would pay him a higher commission, but he was confident that, in time, it would generate a return that would be higher than with a lower-risk fund. Over the next 10 years, the fund had double-digit returns.
Did Victor act appropriately?
options: Yes, the client's risk tolerance and desire to retire at age 55 were unreasonable.
No, Victor did not act in the client's best interest.
Yes, the client benefited from Victor's actions.
No, in order to sell segregated funds, Victor would be required to have a securities or mutual fund licence.
optionFeedback: Even if a client's goals seem difficult to reach, an agent cannot unilaterally ignore their stated risk tolerance.
A positive investment result does not retroactively justify an unsuitable recommendation that violated the client's risk tolerance at the time of sale.
In Canada, a life insurance license allows an agent to sell segregated funds (individual variable insurance contracts) without needing a separate mutual fund or securities license.
questions.explanation: An agent's primary duty is to provide recommendations that match the client's needs and risk profile. Ignoring Joseph's risk-averse nature to chase higher returns (and commissions) is a breach of the duty of care, regardless of the eventual financial outcome.

questions.question:
(PPE-049) EPP
Lorence died at the age of 80. During his life, he had married twice and had two daughters, Lory and Linda, from his first marriage but no children from his second marriage. Lorence did not have much trust in banks and kept almost all of his savings in his home. Lory found a last will and testament drafted 15 years ago naming Linda as the sole beneficiary; however, Linda died a few weeks prior to Lorence.
How will Lorence's assets be distributed?
options: His assets will go directly to Lory, his only other known child.
His assets will go to Linda's estate to be distributed according to her will.
His assets will be divided evenly among his 3 remaining next-of-kin according to the provincial rules that apply.
His assets will go to his estate and be distributed in accordance with applicable provincial rules.
optionFeedback: While Lory is a child, the law does not automatically jump to the next child without following the legal process for a lapsed gift or intestacy.
Because Linda predeceased Lorence, the gift to her 'lapses.' A dead person cannot inherit property to then pass it through their own will.
This assumes a specific distribution (3 people) that may not match the actual provincial intestate laws regarding a surviving spouse and children.
questions.explanation: When a sole beneficiary predeceases the testator and there is no "gift over" (backup) or residuary clause, the gift lapses. Since there is no other valid direction in the will, the assets fall into the estate to be distributed according to the provincial rules of intestacy.

questions.question:
(PPE-011) EPP
After 10 years of marriage, Jules and Amanda recently divorced. As part of their separation agreement, Jules is required to pay Amanda $5,000 per month in spousal support as well as child support in accordance with provincial child support guidelines. Their child is only two years old, and therefore Jules will likely have to pay child support for 20-plus years. Amanda's lawyer insisted on a clause in the separation agreement that required Jules to purchase life insurance to ensure that the required payments will be made in the event of his death. Jules is responsible for making the premium payments.

Which of the following is most likely true of the policy?
options: Jules is the annuitant, and their son is the beneficiary.
Amanda is the policy owner, and their son is contingent policy owner as well as beneficiary.
Jules is the policy owner, and Amanda is the beneficiary.
By guaranteeing payments, Jules is considered the insurer, and Amanda is the contract holder.
optionFeedback: Jules cannot be the annuitant in a life insurance policy; annuitants are only used in annuity contracts. Additionally, the child would not be the primary beneficiary when the purpose is to protect Amanda's spousal and child support payments.

While Amanda has a strong insurable interest in Jules' life, having the two-year-old child as a contingent owner is impractical and legally problematic. The child cannot hold legal title to insurance.

Jules cannot be the 'insurer'‚Äîhe is the insured. An 'insurer' is the insurance company. Amanda is not the 'contract holder' because Jules, who makes the premium payments, is responsible for holding and maintaining the contract.
questions.explanation:
In life insurance contracts designed to secure financial obligations (like spousal support), the person making the premium payments is typically the policy owner and the insured, while the person being protected by the payments is the beneficiary.

In this case:
‚Ä¢ Jules is the policy owner (he pays the premiums and controls the contract)
‚Ä¢ Jules is the insured (the policy pays out when he dies)
‚Ä¢ Amanda is the beneficiary (she receives the proceeds to fulfill his payment obligations)

Although Amanda has a strong insurable interest and her lawyer negotiated this requirement, she would typically not own the policy herself‚ÄîJules owns it but maintains it for her benefit. This structure is common in spousal support and other obligation-securing life insurance arrangements.

Note: The child, being only two years old, cannot be a policy owner or hold any legal interest in the contract.

questions.question:
(PPE-027) EPP
What is a "career agent"?
options: One who is not insurance licenced but can offer creditor insurance on behalf of his or her employer.
One who represents only one insurer.
One who is paid a salary as opposed to a commission.
One who sells insurance through a managing general agent (MGA).
optionFeedback: This describes an "incidental sale of insurance," which often applies to employees of businesses like banks or dealerships who offer insurance secondary to their main business.
While some career agents may receive a training stipend, they are primarily commission-based professionals rather than salaried employees.
Agents working through an MGA are typically independent advisors who can represent multiple carriers.

questions.question:
(PPE-032) EPP
Danielle and Dustin saved for years to purchase their first home, and they have finally bought a single-family house in the suburbs. The purchase price was $525,000, and they were able to make a down payment of $125,000. At the time of purchase, Franco, the mortgage advisor at Big Bank, advised them to purchase mortgage insurance through the bank, which would pay out the outstanding mortgage balance in the event that Danielle or Dustin dies before the loan has been fully repaid. They agreed. The premium will be paid in conjunction with their mortgage payments and will add $85 to the amount that is debited from their account twice per month. Sunny is an independent, licensed life insurance agent. He met with Danielle and Dustin to discuss their life insurance needs and learned about the creditor insurance that they have in place with Big Bank. He suggested that a renewable convertible (RC) T-10 policy from one of the companies that they can contract with would be more appropriate and likely cheaper. He presented an RC T-10 policy that would cover the outstanding mortgage balance for $100 per month.

Based only on the information in the scenario, how should Danielle and Dustin proceed?
options: The premium on the policy Sunny is recommending is greater than what they are paying for the creditor (mortgage) insurance, so they should maintain the policy at Big Bank.
They should replace the creditor (mortgage) insurance with the policy offered by Sunny but make sure that the new policy is approved before cancelling the original policy.
As most mortgages are for greater than 10 years, the policy that Sunny is recommending is not appropriate.
Franco is guilty of tied selling, which is a prohibited practice. Danielle and Dustin should report Franco to the provincial regulator.
optionFeedback: The bank's premium is $85 twice per month, totaling $170 per month. Sunny's recommendation is $100 per month, which is significantly cheaper.
A Renewable and Convertible (RC) T-10 policy allows for continued coverage or conversion to permanent insurance, making it a flexible and appropriate option for a long-term mortgage.
Offering insurance at the time of a mortgage is not 'coercive tied selling' unless it was made a mandatory condition of obtaining the mortgage itself, which is not indicated here.
questions.explanation:
When replacing any policy, it is a critical ethical and professional standard to ensure the new coverage is fully approved and in force before canceling the existing policy to avoid any gap in protection.

KEY DETAILS FROM THE SCENARIO:

‚Ä¢ Creditor insurance premium: $85 √ó 2 per month = $170/month
‚Ä¢ Sunny's RC T-10 policy: $100/month (significantly cheaper)
‚Ä¢ The RC T-10 is renewable (can be renewed without new medical evidence) and convertible (can be changed to permanent insurance)

WHY OPTION A IS WRONG:
Many candidates misread the premium structure. The $85 is debited TWICE per month, making the total $170/month ‚Äî not $85. Sunny's $100/month policy is clearly cheaper.

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
An RC T-10 policy renews every 10 years and can also be converted to permanent insurance, making it perfectly suitable for a mortgage that exceeds 10 years.

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
Tied selling occurs when obtaining one product (the mortgage) is conditional on purchasing another (the insurance). Franco merely "advised" them ‚Äî he did not require it as a condition of the mortgage.

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Note 1 - Critical Policy Replacement Rule:
When replacing a policy, it is critical to ensure that the clients are approved for the new policy before they cancel the old one. Otherwise, the clients could be left with no insurance if the new policy is not approved for some reason.

Note 2 - Not Tied Selling:
This is not a case of tied selling. Nothing in the scenario suggests that Franco made the purchase of Big Bank's mortgage insurance a condition of getting the mortgage. He simply recommended that Danielle and Dustin purchase the policy from Big Bank, but they would have been free to get the required insurance from any source.

Note 3 - Cost Comparison:
The premium for the policy from Big Bank is $85 twice per month, which equates to $170 per month. This is much more expensive than the policy that Sunny is recommending.

Note 4 - Policy Features:
The policy that Sunny is recommending is renewable and convertible, so it could be renewed for as long as is required to cover the mortgage.

questions.question:
(PPE-007) EPP
Which of the following individuals is also known as the policyholder on a group insurance plan?
options: Plan sponsor
Employee
Certificate holder
Plan member
optionFeedback: Correct! The plan sponsor (usually the employer or an association) is the entity that owns the group contract and is legally recognized as the policyholder.
While employees are often the ones covered, the employer is the one acting as the policyholder in the group insurance contract.
The certificate holder is the individual (such as an employee) who is covered under the plan and receives a certificate of insurance rather than the master policy.
A plan member is the person belonging to the group who is insured under the policy; they do not own the master contract.
questions.explanation:
In group insurance plans, the plan sponsor is the policyholder ‚Äî not the individual members covered under the plan.

KEY TERMINOLOGY:

‚Ä¢ Plan Sponsor/Policyholder: The group itself (usually an employer or association) that owns the master contract
‚Ä¢ Plan Members: The individuals covered under the plan who receive certificates of insurance
‚Ä¢ Certificate Holder: Another term for plan members who hold a certificate (not the policy itself)

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
Employees are typically the ones receiving coverage, but they are not the policyholder. The employer is the entity that holds and owns the group insurance contract.

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
The certificate holder receives a certificate of insurance, not the master policy. They are covered by the plan but do not own it.

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
A plan member is simply an individual insured under the group plan. The member does not own or control the master contract.

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

The group itself (usually an employer) is the actual policyholder, not the members. At some point in time, you or your family may have been covered under a group plan. Did you actually see or even read the policy? The answer to this question is likely "No." The reason you did not see the policy is you were not the policyholder (i.e., the employer). Instead, you were a member under the plan.

Key Points:
‚Ä¢ The group itself (usually an employer), the plan sponsor, and the policyholder are all one and the same.
‚Ä¢ Those covered under the plan are referred to as plan members.

questions.question:
(PPE-033) EPP
Ernest has lived in the province of Newfoundland for the past 74 years. He owns a $500,000 whole life policy that is fully paid up. He would like to change the beneficiary designation from his sons, Grayson and Nelson, to his 14 grandchildren.

How would you advise Ernest?
options: Ernest's policy is paid up. Once a whole life policy becomes paid up, the beneficiary designation can no longer be changed.
Ernest is 74 years old. Once a policyholder is over the age of 70, the beneficiary designation can no longer be changed.
Ernest wants to change the number of beneficiaries to 14. The maximum number of beneficiaries that can be listed on any permanent insurance policy is two.
Ernest is the policyholder. As long as Grayson and Nelson were not listed as irrevocable beneficiaries, he is free to change the beneficiary to whomever he chooses.
optionFeedback: The 'paid-up' status refers to the premium payment schedule; it does not restrict the policyholder's right to manage or change beneficiary designations.
There is no maximum age limit in Canadian insurance law that prevents a mentally competent policyholder from changing their beneficiaries.
Policyholders can generally name as many beneficiaries as they wish; there is no statutory limit of two for permanent insurance policies.
questions.explanation:
A policyholder has the absolute right to change a revocable beneficiary at any time without their consent. The ability to change a beneficiary is NOT restricted by:
‚Ä¢ The policy being paid up
‚Ä¢ The policyholder's age
‚Ä¢ The number of beneficiaries desired

The ONLY restriction is if the beneficiary was designated as IRREVOCABLE, which is not the case here.

KEY DISTINCTIONS:

‚Ä¢ Revocable beneficiary: Can be changed at any time by the policyholder without consent
‚Ä¢ Irrevocable beneficiary: Cannot be changed without the beneficiary's consent (would require Grayson and Nelson's approval)
‚Ä¢ Paid-up status: Only means premiums are no longer required; does not affect policy rights

WHY OPTION A IS WRONG:
A paid-up policy simply means all premiums have been paid in full. This status has no bearing on the policyholder's right to modify beneficiary designations.

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
Canadian insurance law has no age restriction on beneficiary changes for a mentally competent policyholder. Age 74 does not prevent Ernest from making this change.

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
There is no statutory limit on the number of beneficiaries. Ernest can name 14 grandchildren, or even more if he wishes.

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - Revocable vs. Irrevocable:
The beneficiary can be changed at any time by the policyholder provided the beneficiary was not designated as "irrevocable" by the insured. If Grayson and Nelson had been irrevocable beneficiaries, Ernest would not be able to make any changes to the policy without their consent.

Key Point 2 - Beneficiary Status:
While a beneficiary may have rights to the death benefit, he or she is not technically considered a party to the contract. An individual could be the beneficiary on a policy without even knowing that the policy exists.

Key Point 3 - Legal Constraints:
In some cases, a separation agreement could prevent a policyholder from changing the beneficiary even if the former spouse were listed as a revocable beneficiary.

Key Point 4 - Formal Requirements:
The naming of a beneficiary must be in writing; however, from a legal perspective, the designation can take place either with the insurer directly or through the insured's last will and testament.

questions.question:
(PPE-045) EPP
Michael met with his insurance agent on November 4th and completed an application for life insurance. At the time of the application, Michael signed an authorization form allowing the insurer to collect monthly premiums electronically from his chequing account. The application was submitted to ABC Insurance Company on November 5th. The insurer underwrote the application and decided to approve it as applied for on November 12th. Michael's agent delivered the policy on November 13th after confirming that there had been no change in insurability. The free-look period ended on November 23rd.

In the above scenario, on what day was the "offer" made?
options: On November 5th, when the application was delivered to the insurance company.
On November 13th, when the policy was delivered to Michael.
On November 4th, when Michael applied for the policy.
On November 12th, when the insurer approved the policy.
optionFeedback: The submission of the application is typically considered an "invitation to treat" rather than the formal legal offer in this specific exam context.
While Michael expressed intent on this day, the legal "offer" in the formation of this contract is the delivery of the policy by the insurer.
The insurer's internal approval is a step in the process, but the offer is not legally communicated until the policy is delivered on November 13th.
questions.explanation:
In the specific context of insurance contract formation taught in the LLQP, the delivery of the actual policy is considered the "offer," which the client then "accepts" by keeping the policy beyond the delivery date.

CONTRACT FORMATION TIMELINE:

‚Ä¢ November 4th: Michael applies (invitation to treat, not an offer)
‚Ä¢ November 5th: Application submitted to insurer (still not an offer)
‚Ä¢ November 12th: Insurer approves internally (internal decision, not communicated as offer)
‚Ä¢ November 13th: Policy delivered to Michael ‚úì THIS IS THE OFFER
‚Ä¢ November 23rd: Free-look period ends (client's acceptance by retention)

KEY LEGAL PRINCIPLE:
In order for a contract to be valid, there needs to be a valid offer and acceptance.

WHY OPTION A IS WRONG:
The submission of the application is typically considered an "invitation to treat" rather than the formal legal offer. The client is inviting the insurer to make an offer, not making an offer themselves.

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
While Michael expressed intent on November 4th, the legal "offer" in the formation of this contract is the delivery of the policy by the insurer.

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
The insurer's internal approval on November 12th is a step in the process, but the offer is not legally communicated until the policy is delivered on November 13th.

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - The Offer in Insurance:
Delivery of the actual policy is the "offer". The client's decision to take the policy is the "acceptance".

Key Point 2 - Common Misconception:
It is not the application itself that is considered to be the offer; it is the delivery of the policy. The application is an "invitation to treat" ‚Äî the client is inviting the insurer to make them an offer.

questions.question:
(PPE-001) EPP
Peter owns a whole life insurance policy that provides $1,000,000 in coverage. The policy has only been in force for a few years; the cash surrender value is therefore negligible. Peter was recently diagnosed with cancer. His doctors have advised him that treatment is not possible, and he is likely to survive for only a few years at best. Peter's beneficiaries have all predeceased him, so his primary concern is taking care of himself. The whole life policy does not have accelerated death benefits, so he is unable to receive a payout until his death. With the help of his agent, he was able to find an investor who was willing to purchase the policy. The investor agreed to pay Peter $250,000 in exchange for an absolute assignment of the policy.

Did the agent act appropriately?
options: The agent is guilty of trafficking in insurance, which is prohibited in some jurisdictions and discouraged in others.
The agent is guilty of a prohibited practice known as tied selling, which takes advantage of a client in a vulnerable position.
Providing that the agent completed an LIRD signed by himself and Peter, his actions were appropriate given he was acting in Peter's best interest.

The agent's actions are appropriate as long he exercised due diligence by researching and presenting to Peter all of the available options such as applying for a bank loan and providing a collateral assignment.
optionFeedback: Tied selling involves making the purchase of one product a condition for obtaining another; this scenario describes a policy sale to a third party, which is trafficking.
A Life Insurance Replacement Declaration (LIRD) is used for replacing policies, not for assigning ownership to a third-party investor for cash.
While presenting options is good practice, assisting in a transaction that constitutes "trafficking in insurance" remains a violation in many jurisdictions regardless of other options presented.
questions.explanation:
Trafficking in insurance (also known as viatical or life settlements) involves selling a policy to a third party for more than its cash value but less than the death benefit. This is specifically prohibited in jurisdictions like Ontario and generally discouraged by the insurance industry.

WHAT IS TRAFFICKING IN INSURANCE?

Trafficking in insurance occurs when:
‚Ä¢ A policyholder sells their policy to a third-party investor
‚Ä¢ The sale price is more than the cash surrender value
‚Ä¢ The sale price is less than the death benefit
‚Ä¢ The transaction benefits the investor more than the original policyholder

WHY THIS IS PROBLEMATIC:

The scenario illustrates the core ethical issue: Peter receives $250,000 now from his policy worth $1,000,000 at death. However, an investor purchases it at this discounted rate and stands to make approximately $750,000 when Peter dies‚Äîpotentially within just a few years. This creates a questionable incentive structure.

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
Tied selling involves making the purchase of one product a condition for obtaining another (e.g., "buy mortgage insurance to get the mortgage"). This scenario describes a policy sale to a third party, which is trafficking, not tied selling.

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
A Life Insurance Replacement Declaration (LIRD) is used for replacing one insurance policy with another from the same policyholder. It is not used for assigning ownership of a policy to a third-party investor for cash.

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
While presenting options is good practice, assisting in a transaction that constitutes "trafficking in insurance" remains a violation in many jurisdictions regardless of other options presented. Due diligence on alternatives does not legitimize a prohibited transaction.

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - Regulatory Status:
Trafficking in insurance (viatical settlements, life settlements) is specifically prohibited in jurisdictions like Ontario. Even where not explicitly prohibited, it is discouraged by the insurance industry.

Key Point 2 - Industry Consequences:
Some insurance companies will terminate a relationship with an agent who participates or assists in such transactions.

Key Point 3 - The Exaggerated Reality:
Consider this scenario: Someone with a $1,000,000 policy and only months to live receives $80,000 for it. An investor stands to profit $920,000 from their death. Does this seem like the client was taken advantage of? This illustrates why trafficking is discouraged‚Äîit often preys on vulnerable individuals in desperate financial situations.

(PPE-048) EPP
Olga's last will and testament instructed the executor to divide her estate equally between her two children, Michael and Sarah. Sarah is 18 years old, still attends university full time, and has no dependents. Michael is divorced and has sole custody of his five-year-old daughter. Olga and Michael were very close. Once a month, he would visit his mother and spend an entire weekend with her. Last week, while spending the weekend at her home, there was a carbon monoxide leak. Olga and Michael both perished. The autopsy report indicated that Michael died first as he was sleeping in the basement and was closest to the furnace and boiler room.

How will Olga's estate be distributed?
options: Michael's estate will not be entitled to anything. Olga's remaining assets will be divided only among living beneficiaries.
Michael's children will be considered contingent beneficiaries and be entitled to what Michael would have otherwise inherited.
Olga's last will and testament will be declared invalid because one of the named beneficiaries pre-deceased her. Her estate will then be divided according to provincial intestacy rules.

Michael's inheritance will be paid to his estate, which will then be distributed according to his last will and testament or, in the event that he died intestate, according to provincial intestacy rules.
optionFeedback: Under Ontario's Succession Law Reform Act (SLRA), gifts to children do not lapse if they leave surviving issue.
The death of a beneficiary does not invalidate a will; statutory rules or "gift-over" provisions determine how the share is redistributed.
Section 31 specifically distributes the gift as if the child had died intestate after the testator, which bypasses the deceased child's own will to protect their heirs.
questions.explanation:
The "anti-lapse" provision (Section 31 of the SLRA) ensures that if a child predeceases the testator but leaves issue (like Michael's daughter), the gift passes to those descendants rather than lapsing.

KEY FACTS FROM THE SCENARIO:

‚Ä¢ Olga's will: Estate divided equally between Michael and Sarah
‚Ä¢ Michael predeceased Olga (died first in the carbon monoxide incident)
‚Ä¢ Michael has a surviving daughter (5 years old)
‚Ä¢ Normally, a beneficiary must be alive at the testator's death to inherit
‚Ä¢ Exception: Anti-lapse provisions protect descendants

THE ANTI-LAPSE PROVISION:

Under Section 31 of Ontario's Succession Law Reform Act:
‚Ä¢ If a child of the testator predeceases the testator
‚Ä¢ BUT that child leaves surviving issue (children/grandchildren)
‚Ä¢ The gift does NOT lapse
‚Ä¢ Instead, it passes to the deceased child's descendants

HOW THE ESTATE IS DISTRIBUTED:

‚Ä¢ Sarah (alive): Receives 50% of Olga's estate
‚Ä¢ Michael's daughter: Receives the 50% that Michael would have inherited
‚Ä¢ Michael's own will or estate: Does NOT control this distribution

WHY OPTION A IS WRONG:
While it's true that beneficiaries must generally be alive at the testator's death, Ontario's SLRA Section 31 creates an exception for children who leave surviving issue. Michael's daughter inherits his share.

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
The death of a beneficiary does not invalidate the entire will. Statutory anti-lapse rules or "gift-over" provisions in the will determine how that beneficiary's share is redistributed. The will remains valid.

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
Section 31 specifically distributes the gift as if the child had died intestate AFTER the testator. This means Michael's share goes directly to his daughter, bypassing Michael's own will entirely. This protects the grandchild's inheritance.

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - General Rule:
In order for a beneficiary to be valid, he or she must be alive at the time of the testator's death. Michael pre-deceased Olga, and therefore his estate would normally have no entitlement.

Key Point 2 - The Rationale (Illustrated Example):
Consider this scenario: Chuck loved his sister Grace but despised her husband Bobby. Despite this, he named Grace as the sole beneficiary in his $1,000,000 life insurance policy. Grace died a few days before Chuck.

If the beneficiary designation remained valid:
‚Ä¢ The proceeds would be paid to Grace's estate
‚Ä¢ Then likely left to her husband Bobby (as per Grace's will)
‚Ä¢ This would NOT have been Chuck's intentions

Because the beneficiary designation is no longer valid:
‚Ä¢ The proceeds will be paid to Chuck's estate
‚Ä¢ Be distributed according to Chuck's last will and testament (not Grace's)

This illustrates why beneficiaries must be alive‚ÄîBUT the anti-lapse provision for children with surviving issue creates an important exception to protect grandchildren.

‚Ä¢ Provincial Regulator: Can revoke the professional license itself

‚Ä¢ Accepted premiums from clients

(PPE-023) EPP
Carlos was married for 10 years before getting divorced. He vowed to never marry again and remained true to that promise. In his last will, he named his only son, Jake, as sole beneficiary of his estate. At the time of Carlos's death, he had the following assets and liabilities:

ASSETS:
‚Ä¢ House: $500,000 (Registered solely in Carlos's name)
‚Ä¢ Bank account: $10,000 (Solely in Carlos's name)
‚Ä¢ WL insurance policy: $500,000 DB (Jake named as beneficiary in the policy)

LIABILITIES:
‚Ä¢ Mortgage: $450,000 (Registered against home)
‚Ä¢ Line of credit: $90,000 (Unsecured)
‚Ä¢ Credit card: $18,000 (Unsecured)

Putting aside any fees or costs associated with liquidating assets, how much would Carlos's son likely receive?
optionFeedback: While Jake receives nothing from the estate itself because the debts exceed the assets, he still receives the full life insurance death benefit because he is a named beneficiary.
This figure incorrectly assumes Jake receives the insurance plus the gross value of the bank account and house equity without paying the unsecured creditors.

This total likely assumes Jake receives the insurance plus the $50,000 house equity, but it ignores the unsecured debts (LOC and Credit Card) that must be paid before any estate distribution to an heir.
questions.explanation:
Carlos's estate is insolvent because its total assets ($510,000) are less than its total liabilities ($558,000), meaning Jake receives $0 from the estate. However, the $500,000 life insurance benefit passes directly to Jake as the named beneficiary and is protected from the estate's creditors.

THE MATH BREAKDOWN:

ESTATE ASSETS:
‚Ä¢ House: $500,000
‚Ä¢ Bank account: $10,000
‚Ä¢ Total Estate Assets: $510,000

NOTE: The life insurance does NOT form part of the estate because Jake is a named beneficiary.

ESTATE LIABILITIES:
‚Ä¢ Mortgage: $450,000
‚Ä¢ Line of credit: $90,000
‚Ä¢ Credit card: $18,000
‚Ä¢ Total Liabilities: $558,000

NET ESTATE VALUE:
$510,000 (assets) - $558,000 (liabilities) = -$48,000 (INSOLVENT)

WHAT JAKE RECEIVES:
‚Ä¢ From the estate: $0 (estate is bankrupt)
‚Ä¢ From life insurance: $500,000 (protected from creditors)
‚Ä¢ TOTAL: $500,000

KEY LEGAL PRINCIPLE:

Provincial insurance legislation states that insurance proceeds payable to protected class beneficiaries (spouse, child, grandchild, etc.) do NOT form part of the deceased's estate. In addition to this protection, Jake was named as beneficiary in the policy itself; therefore, the insurer would pay the $500,000 death benefit directly to Jake.

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
While Jake receives nothing from the estate itself (because debts exceed assets), he still receives the full $500,000 life insurance death benefit because he is a named beneficiary and insurance proceeds to protected class beneficiaries are exempt from estate creditors.

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
This figure ($560,000) incorrectly assumes Jake receives:
‚Ä¢ The $500,000 insurance (correct)
‚Ä¢ Plus the $10,000 bank account
‚Ä¢ Plus $50,000 in house equity ($500,000 house - $450,000 mortgage)

But it ignores that the unsecured creditors ($90,000 + $18,000 = $108,000) must be paid from the estate's remaining assets before any distribution to heirs. The estate is insolvent, so Jake gets nothing from it.

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
This total ($550,000) likely assumes Jake receives:
‚Ä¢ The $500,000 insurance (correct)
‚Ä¢ Plus $50,000 in house equity

But again, it ignores that the unsecured debts must be paid before estate distribution. After paying the mortgage, only $50,000 remains, which is insufficient to cover the $108,000 in unsecured debts.

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - Executor's First Responsibility:
The first responsibility of an executor is to ensure the deceased's final expenses (includes debts and taxes) are paid. It is entirely possible that the deceased's debts exceed his or her assets, essentially bankrupting the estate and leaving no assets available for the named beneficiaries.

Key Point 2 - Life Insurance Protection:
Provincial insurance legislation states that insurance proceeds payable to protected class beneficiaries (spouse, child, grandchild, etc.) do not form part of the deceased's estate. Jake was named as beneficiary in the policy itself; therefore, the insurer would pay the $500,000 death benefit directly to Jake.

Key Point 3 - Insolvent Estate Result:
Carlos's remaining estate assets are not sufficient to cover his outstanding debts; therefore, Jake can expect to receive nothing further as a beneficiary of the estate (though he does receive the insurance proceeds).

Nash suffered a severe back injury several years ago that has left him unable to perform the necessary duties of his job. Term insurance
optionFeedback: The 10-day free look period generally applies to accident and sickness contracts, which includes critical illness insurance.

questions.explanation:

The free look period (also called the "right of rescission") allows a client to:
‚Ä¢ Review the policy after delivery
‚Ä¢ Cancel within a specified timeframe
‚Ä¢ Receive a full refund of premiums paid

STANDARD FREE LOOK PERIODS:

‚úì LIFE INSURANCE: 10 days minimum
‚Ä¢ Term insurance: 10 days ‚úì
‚Ä¢ Whole life insurance: 10 days ‚úì
‚Ä¢ Universal life insurance: 10 days ‚úì

‚úì ACCIDENT & SICKNESS: 10 days
‚Ä¢ Critical illness insurance: 10 days ‚úì
‚Ä¢ Long-term care insurance: 10 days ‚úì
‚Ä¢ Disability insurance: 10 days ‚úì

‚úó INDIVIDUAL VARIABLE INSURANCE CONTRACTS: 2 days only
‚Ä¢ Segregated funds: 2 days ‚úó
‚Ä¢ Investment-linked insurance: 2 days ‚úó

WHY OPTION A IS WRONG:
Critical illness insurance is classified as an accident and sickness contract. All accident and sickness contracts have the standard 10-day free look period. This option DOES have the 10-day period, so it's not the answer.

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
Long-term care insurance is also considered an accident and sickness contract, which typically carries the 10-day right of rescission. This option DOES have the 10-day period.

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - What It's Called:
The 10-day free look period is also called the "right of rescission."

Key Point 2 - What Contracts Get It:
This right is available on:
‚Ä¢ Life insurance contracts
‚Ä¢ Accident and sickness contracts

Key Point 3 - The Segregated Fund Exception:
In the case of individual variable insurance contracts (i.e., segregated funds), the 10-day free look period does NOT apply. Segregated funds have a right of rescission, but it is generally two days from issue, not ten days.

Key Point 4 - Important Segregated Fund Rescission Details:
With a segregated fund contract rescission:
‚Ä¢ Commissions and fees are reversed ‚úì
‚Ä¢ There is no redemption charge ‚úì

If the question says: "would NOT apply"

(PPE-009) EPP
Betty obtained a $75,000 loan from a bank and established an aggressive repayment schedule. She assigned a $150,000 whole life policy, on which her husband was named as revocable beneficiary, as collateral for the loan. Betty has just died. The outstanding balance on the loan is $45,000, including interest, and the life insurance policy currently has a cash surrender value of $12,000.

To what portion of the death benefit would the bank be entitled?
options: The bank would be entitled to $45,000 of the death benefit. The balance would be paid to Betty's husband.
Under the assignment, the bank is considered the new policy owner and would thus be entitled to the full death benefit.
The bank would receive an amount equivalent to the cash surrender value of the policy. The remainder would be paid to Betty's husband.
Nothing. Her husband is part of the protected class and therefore the full death benefit would be paid to him.
optionFeedback: A collateral assignment does not transfer ownership of the policy; it only provides a claim against the proceeds to secure a debt. An absolute assignment would be required to change the policy owner.
The cash surrender value ($12,000) is what the owner can access while alive or upon surrendering the policy. Upon death, the much larger death benefit is triggered to cover the debt.
While a spouse may belong to a protected class, the policy owner (Betty) waived that protection for the portion of the debt when she signed the collateral assignment.
questions.explanation:
In a collateral assignment, the assignee (the bank) is entitled to the amount of the debt at the time of death, which is $45,000. The remainder of the $150,000 death benefit is then paid to the named beneficiary.

THE MATH BREAKDOWN:

‚Ä¢ Death benefit: $150,000
‚Ä¢ Outstanding loan balance (including interest): $45,000
‚Ä¢ Cash surrender value: $12,000 (irrelevant for death benefit calculation)

DISTRIBUTION:
‚Ä¢ Bank receives: $45,000 (the debt amount)
‚Ä¢ Husband receives: $105,000 ($150,000 - $45,000)

KEY CONCEPTS:

COLLATERAL ASSIGNMENT vs. ABSOLUTE ASSIGNMENT:

Collateral Assignment:
‚Ä¢ Does NOT transfer policy ownership
‚Ä¢ Bank has a claim only to the extent of the debt
‚Ä¢ Owner retains control of the policy
‚Ä¢ Assignee receives debt amount only
‚Ä¢ Remainder goes to beneficiary

Absolute Assignment:
‚Ä¢ DOES transfer policy ownership
‚Ä¢ New owner has full rights to the policy
‚Ä¢ New owner receives the entire death benefit
‚Ä¢ Original beneficiary has no claim

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
The bank is NOT the new policy owner. A collateral assignment does not transfer ownership; it only provides a security interest or claim against the proceeds to secure a debt. An absolute assignment would be required to actually change the policy owner. Betty remains the owner.

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
The cash surrender value ($12,000) is what the policy owner can access while alive by surrendering (canceling) the policy. Upon death, the death benefit is triggered, not the CSV. The bank's claim is against the death benefit ($150,000), not the CSV. The bank receives the loan balance ($45,000), not the CSV.

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
While a spouse may belong to a "protected class" (meaning insurance proceeds to spouses are typically protected from creditors), the policy owner (Betty) waived that protection for the portion of the debt when she voluntarily signed the collateral assignment. The bank has priority for the debt amount.

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - Protected Class Protection is Waived:
While a spouse is part of the protected class, that protection was waived when Betty signed the collateral assignment. By voluntarily assigning the policy as collateral, Betty gave the bank a secured claim against the death benefit for the amount of the loan.

Key Point 2 - Revocable vs. Irrevocable Matters:
Betty's husband cannot dispute the assignment because he was named as a revocable beneficiary, not an irrevocable beneficiary. A revocable beneficiary has no vested rights and cannot prevent the policy owner from making changes or assignments.

Key Point 3 - Payment Priority:
The death benefit would be used to pay the bank the amount owed under the loan FIRST, with the remainder being paid to Betty's husband as the named beneficiary. The order is:
1. Bank receives the debt amount ($45,000)
2. Beneficiary receives the remainder ($105,000)

Key Point 4 - CSV is Irrelevant at Death:
The $12,000 cash surrender value is completely irrelevant in this calculation. CSV only matters if the policy is surrendered while the insured is alive. At death, the full death benefit is paid out.

Martin owned an $800,000 life insurance policy on his business partner's life. The policy has been in force for many years and has a cash value of $210,000. Upon Martin's death, Justin, who was named as contingent policy holder, became the new owner of the policy. Shortly after Martin's death, the insurance company filed for bankruptcy. optionFeedback: $680,000 does not correspond to the Assuris protection calculation for a $210,000 cash value.
$60,000 was the previous fixed limit for cash value protection before the recent increase in Assuris coverage levels.
$200,000 was a previous limit for death benefit protection, but it does not apply to the cash value surrender calculation.
questions.explanation:
For cash value (accumulation value) benefits, Assuris guarantees that policyholders will retain the greater of $100,000 or 90% of the promised benefit. Since 90% of $210,000 is $189,000‚Äîwhich is greater than $100,000‚ÄîJustin is entitled to $189,000.

Who is the life insured?
‚Ä¢ Martin owned the policy, but his BUSINESS PARTNER was the life insured
‚Ä¢ When Martin (the owner) died, NO death benefit was paid
‚Ä¢ Instead, ownership transferred to Justin (contingent policy holder)
‚Ä¢ The business partner is still alive

What is Justin doing?
‚Ä¢ Justin wants to SURRENDER the policy
‚Ä¢ Surrender = cash out the cash value
‚Ä¢ This is NOT a death benefit claim

What matters for Assuris?
‚Ä¢ The CASH VALUE: $210,000
‚Ä¢ The $800,000 face amount is irrelevant here (it's a distractor)

THE ASSURIS CALCULATION:

For CASH VALUE (accumulation value), Assuris protects:

The GREATER of:
‚Ä¢ 100% of cash value up to $100,000, OR
‚Ä¢ 90% of the cash value

Step 1: Calculate 90% of cash value
$210,000 √ó 90% = $189,000

Step 2: Compare to the $100,000 threshold
$189,000 > $100,000

Step 3: Choose the greater amount
$189,000 is greater, so that's what Assuris will protect

‚úì Justin receives: $189,000

WHY OPTION A IS WRONG:
$680,000 appears to be 85% of the $800,000 face amount. However:
‚Ä¢ The policy is being surrendered, not claimed as a death benefit
‚Ä¢ Face amount is irrelevant for cash value protection
‚Ä¢ This doesn't correspond to any Assuris protection formula for cash value

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
$60,000 was the previous fixed limit for health insurance cash value protection before Assuris increased coverage levels. It's an outdated number and doesn't apply to this scenario or current Assuris rules.

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
$200,000 was a previous limit for death benefit protection under Assuris (85% or $200,000, whichever is less). However:
‚Ä¢ This is NOT a death benefit claim
‚Ä¢ Justin is surrendering for cash value
‚Ä¢ Death benefit protection formulas don't apply here

ASSURIS PROTECTION SUMMARY:

DEATH BENEFIT:
‚Ä¢ 85% of death benefit OR $200,000 (whichever is less)

CASH VALUE:
‚Ä¢ 90% of cash value OR $100,000 (whichever is GREATER)
‚Ä¢ Note: For amounts under $111,111, you'd get 100% up to $100,000
‚Ä¢ For amounts over $111,111, you get 90%

‚Ä¢ 85% of benefit OR $5,000/month (whichever is less)

‚Ä¢ 85% of benefit OR $60,000 (whichever is less)

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - Reading Comprehension is Critical:
Martin was not the life-insured (his business partner was), and therefore the death benefit was not payable upon his death. We know this because, when Martin died, instead of the death benefit being payable, ownership of the policy transitioned to the contingent policy owner.

Key Point 2 - This is About Cash Value, Not Death Benefit:
Therefore, this question is referring to Assuris's coverage on the cash value as opposed to the death benefit itself.

Key Point 3 - The Cash Value Formula:
In terms of the cash value, Assuris covers the GREATER of:
‚Ä¢ 100% of the cash value up to $100,000, OR
‚Ä¢ 90% of the cash value

Calculation:
$210,000 cash value √ó 90% = $189,000

üß† EXAM KILL-SWITCH RULE:

If you see:
‚Ä¢ Insurer bankrupt
‚Ä¢ Policy surrendered
‚Ä¢ Cash value mentioned

Your brain must jump to: "90% of cash value."

Nathaniel had a vivid dream one night that his neighbour Brooks was going to die in a horrific car accident. On the other hand, Brooks's wife Amanda does not believe in the supernatural and laughed it off. Once the policy is in place, Nathaniel would pay her a lump sum amount in exchange for absolutely assigning the policy to him.

options: Nothing. The absolute assignment would be valid because an insurable interest need only exist at the time the policy is issued.

The absolute assignment would not be valid because the new policy holder did not have an insurable interest in the life insured at the time of transfer.

questions.explanation:
This scenario is not really about insurable interest timing ‚Äî that's the bait. The real issue is INTENT and STRUCTURE. An inducement to apply for new life insurance and then assign ownership to another party in exchange for payment is a form of trafficking in insurance. Many Canadian jurisdictions prohibit this practice outright, and it is universally discouraged by the industry.

STEP 1: YES, INSURABLE INTEREST TECHNICALLY EXISTS (but don't stop there)

‚Ä¢ Amanda (wife) does have an insurable interest in her husband Brooks
‚Ä¢ So the policy can be validly issued in her name
‚Ä¢ This is where weak candidates stop thinking. The exam doesn't.

STEP 2: LOOK AT THE PLAN (this is where it goes bad)

Nathaniel's proposal is:
‚Ä¢ Policy issued to wife ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ Immediate or planned absolute assignment to Nathaniel ‚ùå
‚Ä¢ Nathaniel has NO insurable interest in Brooks
‚Ä¢ Purpose = financial gain from another person's death

üëâ This is a textbook setup for trafficking in insurance.

STEP 3: WHY AGENTS MUST BE CONCERNED

Trafficking in insurance involves:
‚Ä¢ Policies taken out for the benefit of third parties
‚Ä¢ Third parties who lack insurable interest
‚Ä¢ Arrangements designed from the outset to transfer ownership
‚Ä¢ Exchange of money for the policy assignment

Even if technically legal in some jurisdictions, it is:
‚Ä¢ Specifically prohibited in some (like Ontario)
‚Ä¢ Strongly discouraged everywhere
‚Ä¢ A major red flag for agents under E&O and ethics rules

WHY OPTION A IS WRONG:
"Nothing... insurable interest need only exist at the time the policy is issued."

‚Ä¢ True in isolation
‚Ä¢ But ignores the pre-arranged assignment for payment
‚Ä¢ Exam trap: correct fact, wrong conclusion
‚Ä¢ Insurable interest timing is irrelevant when trafficking intent exists from the start

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
"Nothing... insurable interest need only exist at the time the policy is applied for."

‚Ä¢ Same problem as Option A
‚Ä¢ Timing is irrelevant when trafficking intent exists
‚Ä¢ The validity of insurable interest at application does not override the prohibitions against subsequent sale of the policy for profit

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
"Assignment would not be valid because new owner lacked insurable interest."

‚Ä¢ Assignments can be valid even without insurable interest (e.g., gifts, sales)
‚Ä¢ That's not the legal flaw here
‚Ä¢ The flaw is ethical + regulatory (trafficking), not technical validity
‚Ä¢ In most jurisdictions, an assignee does not strictly need an insurable interest for a legitimate transfer, but the issue here is the "inducement" and exchange for payment

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - What is Trafficking:
Trafficking in insurance is specifically prohibited in some jurisdictions and discouraged by the industry as a whole. An inducement to apply for new life insurance and then assign ownership of the policy to another party in exchange for payment is a form of trafficking insurance.

Key Point 2 - Insurable Interest is a Distraction:
While the learning point to this question has nothing to do with insurable interest, you should know that such interest only needs to exist at the time a policy is applied for and issued. The issue with the scenario is that the upfront intent was to purchase the policy and then assign it for a fee.

Key Point 3 - The Pre-Arrangement is the Problem:
The problem isn't the assignment itself ‚Äî it's that the arrangement was planned from the beginning. Nathaniel induced Amanda to take out the policy with the understanding that she would immediately assign it to him for payment. This transforms a legitimate insurance transaction into trafficking.

Key Point 4 - Why This Matters:
‚Ä¢ Nathaniel has no insurable interest in Brooks
‚Ä¢ Nathaniel profits from Brooks's death
‚Ä¢ This creates a perverse incentive (financial gain from death)
‚Ä¢ It violates the fundamental principle of insurance: indemnification, not speculation

üß† EXAM KILL RULE:

If you see:
‚Ä¢ Stranger funding or buying a policy
‚Ä¢ Planned assignment to someone with no insurable interest
‚Ä¢ Profit motive tied to death
‚Ä¢ Pre-arranged transfer for payment

Your answer is almost always: Trafficking in insurance

The dream story, the neighbour relationship, and the financial difficulties are all narrative distractions. Focus on the structure: induced application + pre-arranged assignment for money = trafficking.

(PPE-012) EPP
Bonnie and Clyde were high school sweethearts. They were bad influences on each other, resulting in several brushes with the law. Bonnie's parents decided to move to another province in order to end their daughter's relationship with Clyde. A few decades passed before Bonnie and Clyde reunited again through social media. Bonnie had gone through a nasty divorce and had depleted most of her life savings in legal fees. Her only remaining asset was a whole life insurance policy that had a minimal cash value. As they sped away from the scene of the crime, Clyde lost control of the car, and they hit an oncoming car. Bonnie was announced dead at the scene. Clyde had both of his legs severed in the car accident. He died 45 days later.

How would the claims on their policies be handled?
options: Neither policy will pay the claim.
The death benefit on Bonnie's policy will be paid to Clyde's estate and be distributed according to his last will and testament. The claim on Clyde's CI policy will be paid to his estate.
The death benefit on Bonnie's life insurance policy will not be paid. The claim on Clyde's CI policy will be paid if an innocent party was named as beneficiary.
The life insurance proceeds will be paid to Bonnie's surviving heirs. The CI benefit will be paid to Clyde's beneficiaries.
optionFeedback: Because both Bonnie and Clyde were involved in the criminal act (the bank robbery), neither can profit from the crime, and the exclusions apply to both policies.
While innocent beneficiaries are sometimes protected, the exclusion for "death or injury while committing a criminal act" typically voids the claim regardless of who is named as the payee.
Public policy in Canada dictates that insurance cannot be used to benefit from illegal activities. Since the accident occurred during the getaway, both claims are barred.
questions.explanation:
Under the principle of "public policy" and standard exclusion clauses, an insurer will not pay for loss or death that occurs while the insured is committing a criminal act. Although Clyde survived the 30-day CI period, the injury was sustained during the commission of a crime, nullifying both the life and CI claims.

CORE LLQP PRINCIPLE:

Insurance cannot be used to indemnify or reward criminal activity.

If a loss occurs while committing a criminal act, insurers are allowed ‚Äî and expected ‚Äî to deny the claim.

APPLY IT TO EACH POLICY:

üß© 1Ô∏è‚É£ BONNIE'S LIFE INSURANCE POLICY

‚Ä¢ Bonnie dies during an armed bank robbery
‚Ä¢ Death occurs in the commission of a crime
‚Ä¢ Public policy + standard exclusions apply

üëâ No death benefit is payable:
‚Ä¢ Not to Clyde (named beneficiary)
‚Ä¢ Not to heirs
‚Ä¢ Not to the estate
‚Ä¢ The policy does not respond at all

üß© 2Ô∏è‚É£ CLYDE'S CRITICAL ILLNESS (CI) POLICY

This is the tricky part that fools people.

Facts:
‚Ä¢ Covered condition (loss of limbs) ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ Survival period met (45 days > 30 days) ‚úÖ

BUT‚Ä¶
‚Ä¢ Injury occurred during the commission of a serious crime
‚Ä¢ CI policies include illegal acts / criminal activity exclusions
‚Ä¢ Public policy overrides technical eligibility

üëâ CI claim is also denied

This is exactly why the examiner added:
‚Ä¢ The robbery
‚Ä¢ The chase
‚Ä¢ The accident timing during getaway

It's deliberate.

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
"Death benefit paid to Clyde's estate, CI paid to his estate."

‚Ä¢ Sounds logical if you ignore the crime
‚Ä¢ Because both Bonnie and Clyde were involved in the criminal act (bank robbery), neither can profit from the crime
‚Ä¢ Exclusions apply to BOTH policies
‚Ä¢ Estate does not cure criminal exclusion
‚Ä¢ Public policy blocks the claim at the source

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
"Bonnie's policy won't pay, but Clyde's CI will pay if innocent beneficiary."

‚Ä¢ While innocent beneficiaries are sometimes protected in other contexts
‚Ä¢ The exclusion for "death or injury while committing a criminal act" typically voids the claim regardless of who is named as the payee
‚Ä¢ CI benefits are not about beneficiary innocence
‚Ä¢ The claim itself is invalid due to the criminal act
‚Ä¢ This option fails public policy

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
"Life proceeds to Bonnie's heirs, CI to Clyde's beneficiaries."

‚Ä¢ Sounds compassionate and fair
‚Ä¢ Completely fails public policy principle
‚Ä¢ Public policy in Canada dictates that insurance cannot be used to benefit from illegal activities
‚Ä¢ Since the accident occurred during the getaway from a bank robbery, both claims are barred
‚Ä¢ The exam does not reward moral sympathy over legal principle

KEY DISTINCTIONS:

What people get wrong:
"But Clyde survived 30 days! Doesn't that mean the CI claim is valid?"

NO. Technical eligibility ‚â† valid claim when criminal activity is involved.

The survival period is irrelevant if the injury itself occurred during the commission of a crime.

"But what if an innocent person was the beneficiary?"

Doesn't matter. The exclusion applies to the CLAIM, not the beneficiary. If the insured person was committing a crime when the loss occurred, the policy doesn't pay ‚Äî period.

"Isn't this harsh? What about their families?"

Public policy is intentionally harsh to prevent people from using insurance as a "safety net" for criminal activity. The law will not allow insurance to become a tool for profiting from crime.

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - Public Policy Trumps Everything:
Under the principle of "public policy," an insurer will not pay for loss or death that occurs while the insured is committing a criminal act. This applies even if all other policy conditions are met (coverage amount, survival periods, beneficiary designations, etc.).

Key Point 2 - Criminal Activity Exclusions are Standard:
All insurance policies (life, CI, disability, property) contain exclusions for illegal acts or criminal activity. These are not optional ‚Äî they reflect fundamental legal principles.

Key Point 3 - Survival Period is Irrelevant:
Although Clyde survived the 30-day CI waiting period (he died 45 days later), the injury was sustained during the commission of a crime (bank robbery and getaway). This nullifies both the life and CI claims, regardless of technical eligibility.

Key Point 4 - No One Benefits from Crime:
Neither the insured, their estate, nor their beneficiaries can profit from insurance when the loss occurred during criminal activity. This principle protects the integrity of the insurance system.

üß† EXAM MEMORY HOOK (CRITICAL):

If you see:
‚Ä¢ Robbery
‚Ä¢ Drug deal
‚Ä¢ Assault
‚Ä¢ Getaway
‚Ä¢ Crime explicitly described in the scenario

Your brain should immediately say: "Public policy ‚Üí NO PAYOUT."

Even if:
‚Ä¢ Survival period is met ‚úì
‚Ä¢ Condition is covered ‚úì
‚Ä¢ Beneficiary is innocent ‚úì

Crime kills the claim. Every time. No exceptions.

The backstory about high school sweethearts, divorce, social media reunion ‚Äî all narrative distractions. Focus on: Crime + Loss during crime = No claim.

questions.question:
(PPE-002) EPP
Michael is applying for life insurance. On his application he indicated that he was a non-smoker. The agent noticed that Michael had an ashtray on his coffee table and his clothing smelled of smoke.

How should the agent proceed?
options: The agent should explain the risk that Michael faces if he does not provide complete and accurate disclosure.
It is in the client's best interest to obtain the requested insurance. Therefore, the agent should record Michael's answers as provided.
The agent should not comment because he is refrained from coaching the client when answering questions on the life insurance application.
The agent should change Michael's answer to indicate he is a smoker.
optionFeedback: While agents must act in the client's best interest, recording a known or suspected false statement is a breach of the agent's fiduciary duty to the insurer and can result in the claim being denied later.
Clarifying the consequences of providing false information is not considered improper "coaching"; it is part of the agent's duty to provide proper advice and ensure the application is accurate.
The agent must never alter a client's answer without the client's consent and initialling of the change. The correct process is to discuss it with the client first.
questions.explanation:
The agent's primary ethical duty is to ensure the client understands that misrepresentation (lying about smoking status) can lead to a denial of claims or policy cancellation. If Michael still refuses to change his answer, the agent must then document their observations in the agent's report section of the application.

STEP 1: WHAT DID THE AGENT OBSERVE?

‚Ä¢ Ashtray on the coffee table
‚Ä¢ Clothing smells of smoke
‚Ä¢ Application says non-smoker

That's a red flag, not proof. But it's an inconsistency that must be addressed.

STEP 2: WHAT IS THE AGENT'S DUTY?

The agent must:
‚Ä¢ Act in utmost good faith
‚Ä¢ Ensure the client understands:
  - Duty of disclosure
  - Consequences of misrepresentation (policy void, claim denial, rescission)

üëâ The correct action is education and warning, not correction or silence.

STEP 3: THE CORRECT PROCEDURE

1. Explain the risks of incomplete or inaccurate disclosure
2. Give Michael the opportunity to correct his own answer
3. If Michael maintains his answer despite your warning, document your observations in the agent's report section
4. Let the underwriter make the final decision

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
"Record answers as provided."

‚Ä¢ While agents must act in the client's best interest, this approach violates duty of care
‚Ä¢ Recording a known or suspected false statement is a breach of the agent's fiduciary duty to the insurer
‚Ä¢ This facilitates misrepresentation
‚Ä¢ The claim can be denied or rescinded later when the truth comes out
‚Ä¢ "Best interest" does not mean helping someone commit fraud

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
"Should not comment due to coaching rules."

‚Ä¢ Misunderstands what "coaching" means
‚Ä¢ Coaching = telling the client what answer to give
‚Ä¢ Warning = explaining the consequences of providing false information
‚Ä¢ These are opposite actions
‚Ä¢ Clarifying the consequences of false disclosure is PART of the agent's duty to provide proper advice
‚Ä¢ It ensures the application is accurate

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
"Change the answer to smoker."

‚Ä¢ The agent must NEVER alter a client's answer without explicit consent
‚Ä¢ The client must initial any changes
‚Ä¢ Changing the answer without Michael's agreement is itself a form of misrepresentation
‚Ä¢ The correct process is:
  1. Discuss with the client first
  2. Give the client the chance to correct their own answer
  3. Only then can a change be documented with client initials

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - Duty of Disclosure:
Both the insured and the agent have a duty to ensure the application contains complete and accurate information. Misrepresentation (providing false or incomplete information) can result in:
‚Ä¢ Policy rescission (cancellation from the beginning)
‚Ä¢ Claim denial
‚Ä¢ Policy cancellation

Key Point 2 - The Agent's Role:
The agent must:
‚Ä¢ Educate the client on the importance of accuracy
‚Ä¢ Warn the client about consequences of misrepresentation
‚Ä¢ Document any inconsistencies or observations
‚Ä¢ Let the underwriter make the final determination

Key Point 3 - What the Agent Must NOT Do:
‚ùå Cannot change answers on the application without client consent and initials
‚ùå Cannot ignore obvious inconsistencies
‚ùå Cannot coach by telling the client what to answer
‚ùå Cannot record false statements simply to "help the client get approved"

Key Point 4 - Documentation is Critical:
If Michael maintains his non-smoker answer despite the agent's explanation of consequences, the agent MUST document their observations in the agent's report section of the application. This creates a record that:
‚Ä¢ The inconsistency was noted
‚Ä¢ The client was warned
‚Ä¢ The client chose to maintain their answer
‚Ä¢ This protects the agent and insurer later

Key Point 5 - Duty to the Insurer:
Agents have a fiduciary duty to the INSURER as well as the client. Recording a known or suspected false statement violates this duty and can result in:
‚Ä¢ The agent facing disciplinary action
‚Ä¢ The agent's license being suspended or revoked
‚Ä¢ Claims being denied when the truth emerges

üß† EXAM RULE TO MEMORIZE:

When you suspect misrepresentation:

Warn ‚Üí Document ‚Üí Let the client decide

Never:
‚ùå Guess
‚ùå Alter
‚ùå Ignore

The agent's job is to ensure accuracy and disclosure, not to help the client hide information or to make changes on the client's behalf. Education and documentation are your shields against liability.

(PPE-005) EPP
George is a successful life insurance agent. At the request of one of his most important clients, George met with the client's 20-year old daughter Grace to discuss purchasing a life insurance policy. After learning that Grace was newly married and expecting a child, George realized an immediate need for life insurance. In an effort to assist her in purchasing the needed coverage, he offered to give her part of his commission to help cover the initial premium.

Was George's offer appropriate?
options: Maybe. George's actions are permissible providing he can demonstrate he offers a similar program to clients of a similar demographic.
Maybe. George's actions are permissible providing it is something he offers all potential clients.
No. George's actions constitute rebating, which is an unfair or deceptive sales practice.
Yes. George assisted the client in the purchase of a suitable insurance product.
optionFeedback: Even if offered consistently to a similar demographic, giving back a portion of a commission is a prohibited practice in the insurance industry.
Offering commissions as an inducement to purchase a policy is considered an unfair trade practice regardless of how many clients it is offered to.
While the product may be suitable, the method of assisting with the premium (rebating) is unethical and illegal under insurance regulations.
questions.explanation:
George's offer to give a portion of his commission to the client is known as rebating. In Canada, rebating is considered an unfair or deceptive trade practice and is strictly prohibited by provincial insurance regulators.

STEP 1: WHAT DID GEORGE DO?

‚Ä¢ Offered to give part of his commission
‚Ä¢ Purpose: help pay the initial premium
‚Ä¢ Given as an inducement to purchase insurance

That's the textbook definition of rebating.

STEP 2: WHAT IS REBATING?

Rebating is:
‚Ä¢ Offering cash, commission, gifts, or value
‚Ä¢ Not stated in the policy
‚Ä¢ To induce someone to buy insurance

üëâ It is considered:
‚Ä¢ Unfair
‚Ä¢ Deceptive
‚Ä¢ Prohibited in most jurisdictions
‚Ä¢ Intent does not matter
‚Ä¢ Good intentions do not save you

WHY OPTION A IS WRONG:
"Maybe. Permissible if offered to similar demographics."

‚Ä¢ Misunderstands the rule
‚Ä¢ Non-discrimination rules ‚â† rebating rules
‚Ä¢ You cannot rebate even if everyone in a demographic gets it
‚Ä¢ Rebating is prohibited REGARDLESS of consistency or fairness in application
‚Ä¢ The prohibited practice is the rebating itself, not the discrimination

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
"Maybe. Permissible if offered to all potential clients."

‚Ä¢ Still rebating
‚Ä¢ Widespread illegality doesn't become legal
‚Ä¢ Just because everyone gets the rebate doesn't make it compliant
‚Ä¢ If George offered every single client a commission rebate, it would STILL be prohibited
‚Ä¢ The practice itself is the violation, not the selectivity

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG:
"Yes. George assisted in the purchase of a suitable insurance product."

‚Ä¢ Suitability of the product is irrelevant to the compliance issue
‚Ä¢ The product may be perfectly suitable for Grace's needs
‚Ä¢ But the METHOD of facilitating the purchase (rebating) is illegal
‚Ä¢ Providing a suitable product through prohibited means is still a violation
‚Ä¢ Two rights don't make a compliance issue right

KEY DISTINCTIONS:

WHAT IS ALLOWED:
‚Ä¢ Recommending appropriate coverage
‚Ä¢ Explaining the benefits of the policy
‚Ä¢ Helping the client understand their needs
‚Ä¢ Properly disclosing commission and fees

WHAT IS NOT ALLOWED:
‚ùå Giving back commission
‚ùå Paying part of the premium
‚ùå Offering cash incentives
‚ùå Providing gifts as inducements
‚ùå Any value offered to reduce the client's out-of-pocket cost

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - Intent Doesn't Matter:
Even though George's intentions were good (helping Grace afford coverage for her young family), the practice of rebating is strictly prohibited. Regulators don't care about the "why" ‚Äî they care about the "what." Rebating is rebating, whether it's generous or unfair.

Key Point 2 - Why Rebating is Prohibited:
Rebating is considered an unfair or deceptive trade practice because:
‚Ä¢ It can encourage clients to purchase unsuitable coverage
‚Ä¢ It distorts the true cost of insurance
‚Ä¢ It creates unfair competition (agents without rebate programs can't compete)
‚Ä¢ It can lead to over-insurance or under-insurance decisions
‚Ä¢ It violates the principle of transparency

Key Point 3 - Prohibited Forms of Rebating:
Rebating can take many forms:
‚Ä¢ Cash given back to the client
‚Ä¢ Commission returned to the client
‚Ä¢ Gifts or merchandise offered as inducement
‚Ä¢ Paying the client's premium or part of it
‚Ä¢ Waiving fees or charges
‚Ä¢ Any other value offered to reduce the client's cost

Key Point 4 - The Rule is Absolute:
There are no exceptions:
‚Ä¢ It doesn't matter if the policy is suitable
‚Ä¢ It doesn't matter if the client requested help
‚Ä¢ It doesn't matter if the agent is trying to be helpful
‚Ä¢ It doesn't matter if other agents do the same
‚Ä¢ Rebating is always prohibited

Key Point 5 - Consequences:
Agents who engage in rebating face:
‚Ä¢ License suspension or revocation
‚Ä¢ Fines
‚Ä¢ Disciplinary action
‚Ä¢ Criminal charges in some jurisdictions
‚Ä¢ Termination of employment
‚Ä¢ Reputational damage

üß† EXAM KILL RULE:

If you see:
‚Ä¢ Agent giving back commission
‚Ä¢ Helping pay premiums
‚Ä¢ Cash, gifts, or "incentives"
‚Ä¢ "To help the client afford..."
‚Ä¢ "To encourage the client to purchase..."

Your answer is almost always: Rebating ‚Üí prohibited

Key Trigger Phrases:
‚Ä¢ "Offered to give..."
‚Ä¢ "Help cover the premium..."
‚Ä¢ "Inducement to purchase..."
‚Ä¢ "Assist in affording..."

All roads lead to rebating.

The fact that Grace is a new mom, newly married, and genuinely needs insurance is completely irrelevant. The practice itself is the violation, regardless of the circumstances or the suitability of the coverage.
