(PPE-013) EPP
On June 21, 2019, Benjamin was in the United States at a concert that had become the site of a terrorist attack. He has not been seen or heard from since the night of the concert, and it is looking as though he was killed. Benjamin had a life insurance policy that was in force on that date but has since lapsed due to non-payment of premium. In an effort to collect on his life insurance policy, his spouse, who is the named beneficiary in the policy, applied to the courts to have him declared dead.

If the courts declare Benjamin deceased, will the insurance policy pay the death benefit?
options: Yes, since he was declared dead by the courts and the death occurred while the policy was in force.
No, the insurance company will not make payment until Benjamin has been missing for seven years or the body has been located.
No, since the cause of death is the direct result of an illegal activity.
No, since his death was declared well after the policy lapsed.
optionFeedback: While a seven-year absence is a general rule for declaring someone dead, a court can declare someone deceased much sooner if there is strong evidence of immediate peril, such as a terrorist attack.
Terrorism is an illegal activity committed against the insured, not by the insured. Being a victim of a crime does not trigger the criminal act exclusion.
The date of the court declaration is not what determines coverage; rather, it is the established date of death relative to the policy's active status.
questions.explanation:
If a court issues a declaration of death and establishes the date of death as the date the individual went missing (June 21, 2019), the claim is valid because the death occurred while the policy was in force. The subsequent lapse for non-payment of premium does not invalidate a claim for a death that happened prior to the lapse.

THIS QUESTION IS ALL ABOUT WHEN DEATH OCCURRED, NOT WHEN IT WAS DECLARED.

STEP 1: IDENTIFY THE KEY TIMELINE

‚Ä¢ Terrorist attack (presumed date of death): June 21, 2019
‚Ä¢ Policy status on that date: IN FORCE ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ Policy later lapsed: due to non-payment
‚Ä¢ Court declaration of death: after the lapse

üëâ The declaration date is NOT the date of death. It is only legal confirmation of a death that already occurred.

STEP 2: PRESUMPTION OF DEATH RULE

Courts can declare a person dead in two circumstances:

1. After a long unexplained absence (typically 7 years), OR
2. When disappearance occurs under circumstances of peril (e.g., terrorist attack, plane crash, shipwreck)

Once declared:
‚Ä¢ Death is deemed to have occurred at the time of the peril, NOT the court date
‚Ä¢ This is critical

STEP 3: APPLY IT TO THE POLICY

‚Ä¢ Death is deemed to have occurred on June 21, 2019
‚Ä¢ Policy was active on that date

‚û°Ô∏è Death benefit is PAYABLE

‚Ä¢ Policy lapse AFTER death is irrelevant
‚Ä¢ The death benefit is owed for a death that occurred while coverage existed

WHY OPTION B IS WRONG:
"No, must wait seven years or body found."

‚Ä¢ Seven-year rule applies to ordinary disappearances
‚Ä¢ Where there is no evidence of what happened
‚Ä¢ This was a specific peril event (terrorist attack)
‚Ä¢ Courts can declare death much earlier when there is evidence of immediate peril
‚Ä¢ Benjamin disappeared at a terrorist attack ‚Äî immediate peril is established
‚Ä¢ The court can declare him dead without waiting 7 years
‚Ä¢ And death is deemed to have occurred on the date of the peril

WHY OPTION C IS WRONG:
"No, since cause of death is the direct result of an illegal activity."

‚Ä¢ Terrorist attack ‚â† insured committing an illegal act
‚Ä¢ Public policy exclusion applies when the INSURED commits the crime
‚Ä¢ Benjamin is a VICTIM of terrorism, not the perpetrator
‚Ä¢ Being a victim of a crime does not trigger the criminal act exclusion
‚Ä¢ The policy covers deaths from all causes except those specifically excluded
‚Ä¢ Being attacked by a terrorist is not an excluded cause

WHY OPTION D IS WRONG (Common Trap):
"No, since his death was declared well after the policy lapsed."

‚Ä¢ This is the most common wrong answer
‚Ä¢ Confuses declaration date with date of death
‚Ä¢ Coverage depends on WHEN THE DEATH OCCURRED, not when it was legally declared
‚Ä¢ Death is presumed to have occurred on June 21, 2019 (the date of the terrorist attack)
‚Ä¢ On that date, the policy was in force
‚Ä¢ Therefore, the death benefit is payable
‚Ä¢ It doesn't matter that the policy later lapsed
‚Ä¢ You can't un-pay a death benefit by letting the policy lapse after the death already happened

KEY PRINCIPLES:

1. DATE OF DEATH vs. DATE OF DECLARATION
   ‚Ä¢ Date of death = When the person died (or is presumed to have died)
   ‚Ä¢ Date of declaration = When the court legally confirms the death
   ‚Ä¢ These are usually different dates
   ‚Ä¢ Policy coverage is determined by DATE OF DEATH, not declaration date

2. PRESUMPTION OF DEATH FROM PERIL
   ‚Ä¢ When someone disappears under circumstances of specific peril
   ‚Ä¢ Death is PRESUMED to have occurred at the time of the peril
   ‚Ä¢ Not 7 years later
   ‚Ä¢ Not when the body is found
   ‚Ä¢ At the time of the known peril event

3. POLICY STATUS AT TIME OF DEATH
   ‚Ä¢ What matters is whether the policy was in force when death occurred
   ‚Ä¢ Not whether it's in force when the claim is made
   ‚Ä¢ Death that occurs while coverage exists = benefit payable
   ‚Ä¢ Lapse after death doesn't affect payment of a death that already happened

ADDITIONAL LEARNING:

Key Point 1 - Two Types of Death Declaration:
Courts can declare someone deceased in two circumstances:
‚Ä¢ After unexplained absence (typically 7 years) ‚Äî death date presumed as date of disappearance
‚Ä¢ During or immediately after circumstances of specific peril (terrorist attack, plane crash, natural disaster) ‚Äî death date presumed as date of peril

Key Point 2 - Seven-Year Rule Does Not Always Apply:

Key Point 3 - Death Benefit Timing:
